texts.definition: Designed support to handle players entering and leaving ongoing game sessions.
markups: <style="Definition">Designed support to handle players entering and leaving ongoing game sessions.</style>

Players cannot always participate in whole game sessions, having to stop prematurely to do something else. This causes problems for the game design in how it should keep the game balanced and interesting for the remaining gamers, but another type of problem can occur if the gamers that left wants to come back again to the same game session. For this problem the game design needs have mechanisms for re-introducing players without disrupting game balances nor making the effort of the already present players unrewarded in comparison with the returning players.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Many casino games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Roulette">Roulette</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Blackjack">Blackjack</link></style>, consist of many quite quick game instances. This allow players entry points often into the meta game of winning money and the players are also free to leave at the end of each game instance.

The multiplayer arcade game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gauntlet">Gauntlet</link></style> partly supported players leaving and entering the game during a game session. Players whose character had died could start playing again simply by inserting coins and new players could do the same. There was however no graceful way for a player to leave the game when one had a healthy character since that character would keep the others to that area until the abandoned character died (this meant that leaving was worse the more health the character had).

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lego%20Star%20Wars%20series">Lego Star Wars series</link></style> (except the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Boy%20Advance">GBA</link></style> version) supports a second player to at any point join the game with a character, and then leave whenever by simply choosing this option in the game. Given that the gameplay never requires both players and that players can replay levels infinitely the gameplay does not degrade when a player drops out.

All massively multiplayer games need to support <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> since it is impossible to synchronize hundreds or thousands of players spread over the world. This is simplification though, since the game structure may imply dedication to participate (e.g. instances in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>) or that emergent gameplay may have entered a critical phase and all players in a local part of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> need each other (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eve%20Online">Eve Online</link></style> is an example of a game where this can occur). The latter can also easily occur in other genres where <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> is supported, e.g. team-based first person shooters such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enemy%20Territory:%20Quake%20Wars">Enemy Territory: Quake Wars</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style> as well as in real-time tactics games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20in%20Conflict">World in Conflict</link></style>.

All game sessions in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> begin with four human characters but only one of them needs to controlled by human gamers. Those not played by humans are computer-controlled but can be replaced by gamers joining the games session. Likewise, if a gamer leaves the game (or loses network connection) the computer takes control over the character without disruption to the other gamers' gameplay. People can even "pause" the game to take their own short breaks while the other gamers continue with a temporary computer substitute.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> it typically discussed for <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, and when it is used in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> to allow additional players this issues become the same as for <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. It is however rather uncomplicated to have in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> - one can simply use <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style>. Another simply design solution to provide <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> is to have <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style> that are being run by <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> (removing the <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> creates <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-instance-duration">Negotiable Game Instance Duration</link></style>, which although it which lets players control how low game sessions are also requires that this is done in agreement with other players). <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style> offer a form of <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> where the freedom of choosing when to play is modulated by how long the ticks are (although too long ticks can also cause <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>).

For most <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, allowing <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> gameplay requires the ability for the game to support <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, although <style="Link"><link="surrendering">Surrendering</link></style> or a <style="Link"><link="possibility-graceful-surrender">Possibility of Graceful Surrender</link></style> can replace <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Early%20leaving%20Players">Early leaving Players</link></style>. The basic mechanics of supporting <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> are however typically not the main challenge with using the pattern (but <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can avoid <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>), rather it is to maintain <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> for games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. How this can be done typically depends on if the game is based on <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> between the players or not. When games revolve around <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> rather than <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> leaving them can be seen as accepting defeat (indeed, many of them use <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>) and does not need to unbalance gameplay for other players (but see diegetic aspects). Entering the game, i.e. supporting <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, can be more problematic. New or returning players may not need <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in relation to the old players, but at least need <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. The former can be achieved by giving them <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style> or having <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> but this risks that existing players feel that their <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> is lost. This can be avoided by instead having games built around <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> but this centers the entry and exit points to the beginning and end of specific game sessions. The use of <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> can for games based upon <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> but not <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> address issues of <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> but less readily <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>.

For games built on <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, e.g. those using <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, the issue of <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> may also be dealt with through <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>. However, the risk of old players feeling a loss of <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> is lessened since the players typically have <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>. An alternative is to not actually reduce the number of players, either through replacing them with existing or newly-created <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> (as for e.g. in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> (appropriate for <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> games with <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>), or other players taking on extra roles (Theoretically, any type of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> could be introduced but have a stable source of new humans willing to take over for leaving players can be difficult to achieve in a design - use of <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> seems to be a possible starting point). The latter is easy to do in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> (e.g. in roleplaying systems such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>) but require additional account handling in computer-mediated games. The reason these solutions cannot be used for non-cooperative games is than the competition usual is against the other human players and not the other characters so replacing the human with another human or an <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> changes the conflict. The use of <style="Link"><link="invites">Invites</link></style> (present in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> to add new players and in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> to replace <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style>) gives people some control over the flow of players in the game.

<style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> and others <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> need the support of <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> to handle that it difficult to coordinate large groups of players to begin and stop playing at the same time in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. For making players want to return to games supporting <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style>, there are various way to have <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style> including <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

If players are represented in a game through <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> it is easy to show the entering or exiting of the game session by simply adding or removing the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. The removal can be done without causes discrepancies between the theme and the events (i.e. without introducing <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>) in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> if the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> represent expendable units that are easy to kill, since players may time their leaving to when they died and abandoned <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> will probably be killed soon anyway. Introducing new <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> can be trickier but <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> in close proximity to <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> can provide a diegetic explanation.
For other types of games, the use of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> can let the deigetic presentation continue undisturbed when players leave.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

The are typically several reasons for other players to wish to know when another player leaves or joins a game session, e.g. if this will change gameplay, <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> act differently from human players, or if they wish to engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>. This can be done through <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> allows players of <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> to have <style="Link"><link="unsynchronized-game-sessions">Unsynchronized Game Sessions</link></style> and thereby <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style> in that they do not need to adjust their own play sessions to other players sessions. It also frees players from playing at the same time, so the pattern supports <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style>. Besides being able to choose how long time they wish to play, <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> gives the game <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style> since players can use the functionality to define the breaks in game sessions rather than define play sessions, but may cause breaks in a game's <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>. For those games where people can be <style="Link"><link="backseat-gamers">Backseat Gamers</link></style>, the existence of <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> gameplay makes it possible for these people to have <style="Link"><link="tiered-participation">Tiered Participation</link></style> in the game since they can move between these states and playing and back again. For games with <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive Gameplay</link></style>, this can let players smoothly handle transitions between playing and not playing to avoid problematic social encounters. In games where <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> may be perceived, <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> can let players leave gracefully if not wishing to engage any longer in the interaction due to this situation.

When the addition or removal of players requires game elements to likewise be added or removed, this makes <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> require <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> respectively. In games with <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> may provide <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> may be difficult to maintain with games that support <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style>. This since, quite naturally, the players that enter and leave the game cannot have had a strong effect on the overall development of the game as a whole. However, this does allow for a level of <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>.

For games that are supposed to have <style="Link"><link="split-screen-views">Split-Screen Views</link></style>, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> gameplay requires designers to consider how these views should change - if at all - when the number of players change.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Drop-In/Drop-Out</style> allows players to have game sessions that do not overlap much or at all, it can work against the possibility that they gain a sense of <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style> by gaming. However, it also makes <style="Link"><link="ragequitting">Ragequitting</link></style> have very little effect on the gameplay for other players.
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiered-participation">Tiered Participation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unsynchronized-game-sessions">Unsynchronized Game Sessions</link></style>
<style="H4">with <style="Link"><link="backseat-gamers">Backseat Gamers</link></style></style>

<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>

<style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ragequitting">Ragequitting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="split-screen-views">Split-Screen Views</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style>

<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>

<style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>
